mn50:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
mn50:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
mn50:1.2.comm: This sutta serves as a showcase for Moggallāna, who is able to swiftly best Māra and recount a detailed story of past lives.

mn50:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno abbhokāse caṅkamati.
mn50:2.1.eng: At that time Moggallāna was walking mindfully in the open air.

mn50:2.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena māro pāpimā āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa kucchigato hoti koṭṭhamanupaviṭṭho.
mn50:2.2.eng: Now at that time Māra the Wicked had got inside Moggallāna’s belly.
mn50:2.2.comm: Māra is sometimes called Namuci, and in fact seems to descend from the Vedic adversary of that name. Vedic Namuci “the wicked” (pāpmā vai namuciḥ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 12.7.3, Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.4.4) was a wily trickster (māyin, Rig Veda 1.53.7c) who was nonetheless outsmarted by Indra (Rig Veda 5.30.6c), and possessed ineffectual armies reliant on women (Rig Veda 5.30.9a). Buddhist Māra “the wicked” (māro pāpimā) was a wily trickster (passim) who was nonetheless outsmarted by the Buddha and his followers (passim); he possessed ineffectual armies (DN 20:21.3, AN 4.13:2.3, Snp 3.2), and sent his daughters to do his dirty work (SN 4.25). The decapitated head of Namuci introduced death (mṛtyu) in the form of blood to the deathless (amṛta) soma (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 12.7.3.4, Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.4.4), establishing his Pali names Maccurāja, “King of Death” and Māra, “Death”. He appears in a similar guise in Jainism too (Ācaraṅga 1.3.1.3).

mn50:2.4.pli: “kiṃ nu kho me kucchi garugaro viya?
mn50:2.4.eng: “Why now is my belly so very heavy,

mn50:2.5.eng: like I’ve just eaten a load of beans?”
mn50:2.5.comm: T 66 has 猶若食豆, MA 131 猶如食豆, both of which confirm the sense “full of beans”. T 67 on the other hand has 飢人而負重擔, “like a hungry man bearing a heavy load.”

mn50:2.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno caṅkamā orohitvā vihāraṃ pavisitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn50:2.6.eng: Then he stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, sat down on the seat spread out,

mn50:3.1.pli: Nisajja kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paccattaṃ yoniso manasākāsi.

mn50:3.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno māraṃ pāpimantaṃ kucchigataṃ koṭṭhamanupaviṭṭhaṃ.
mn50:3.2.eng: He saw that Māra the Wicked had got inside his belly.

mn50:3.6.eng: Do not harass the Realized One or his disciple.

mn50:3.7.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
mn50:3.7.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

mn50:4.2.pli: “ajānameva kho maṃ ayaṃ samaṇo apassaṃ evamāha:
mn50:4.2.eng: “This ascetic doesn’t really know me or see me when he tells me to come out.

mn50:4.6.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā’ti.

mn50:4.7.pli: Yopissa so satthā sopi maṃ neva khippaṃ jāneyya, kuto pana maṃ ayaṃ sāvako jānissatī”ti?
mn50:4.7.eng: Not even the Teacher could recognize me so quickly, so how could a disciple?”

mn50:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno māraṃ pāpimantaṃ etadavoca:

mn50:5.2.pli: “evampi kho tāhaṃ, pāpima, jānāmi, mā tvaṃ maññittho:
mn50:5.2.eng: “I know you even when you’re like this, Wicked One. Do not think,

mn50:5.6.pli: ‘ajānameva kho maṃ ayaṃ samaṇo apassaṃ evamāha—
mn50:5.6.eng: ‘This ascetic doesn’t really know me or see me when he tells me to come out.

mn50:5.10.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti.

mn50:5.11.pli: Yopissa so satthā sopi maṃ neva khippaṃ jāneyya, kuto pana maṃ ayaṃ sāvako jānissatī’”ti?
mn50:5.11.eng: Not even the Teacher could recognize me so quickly, so how could a disciple?’”

mn50:6.2.pli: “jānameva kho maṃ ayaṃ samaṇo passaṃ evamāha:
mn50:6.2.eng: “This ascetic really does know me and see me when he tells me to come out.”

mn50:6.6.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā’”ti.

mn50:6.7.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa mukhato uggantvā paccaggaḷe aṭṭhāsi.
mn50:6.7.eng: Then Māra came up out of Moggallāna’s mouth and stood against the door.

mn50:7.1.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno māraṃ pāpimantaṃ paccaggaḷe ṭhitaṃ;

mn50:7.3.pli: “etthāpi kho tāhaṃ, pāpima, passāmi; mā tvaṃ maññittho
mn50:7.3.eng: “I see you even there, Wicked One. Do not think,

mn50:7.5.eng: That’s you, Wicked One, standing against the door.

mn50:8.1.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, pāpima, dūsī nāma māro ahosiṃ, tassa me kāḷī nāma bhaginī.
mn50:8.1.eng: Once upon a time, Wicked One, I was a Māra named Dūsī, and I had a sister named Kāḷī.
mn50:8.1.comm: Dūsī the “corrupter” and Kāḷī the “dark lady”, an early mention of a goddess of that name. | This story is also told at Thag 20.1:48.1.

mn50:9.1.pli: Tena kho pana, pāpima, samayena kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno hoti.
mn50:9.1.eng: At that time Kakusandha, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
mn50:9.1.comm: Kakusandha is also mentioned at SN 12.7:1.1, SN 15.20:2.8, DN 14:1.4.4, DN 32:3.8, and Thag 7.5:4.4.

mn50:9.2.pli: Kakusandhassa kho pana, pāpima, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa vidhurasañjīvaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
mn50:9.2.eng: Kakusandha had a fine pair of chief disciples named Vidhura and Sañjīva.

mn50:9.3.pli: Yāvatā kho pana, pāpima, kakusandhassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sāvakā.
mn50:9.3.eng: Of all the disciples of the Buddha Kakusandha,

mn50:9.4.pli: Tesu na ca koci āyasmatā vidhurena samasamo hoti yadidaṃ dhammadesanāya.
mn50:9.4.eng: none were the equal of Venerable Vidhura in teaching Dhamma.

mn50:9.5.pli: Iminā kho evaṃ, pāpima, pariyāyena āyasmato vidhurassa vidhuroteva samaññā udapādi.
mn50:9.5.eng: And that’s how he came to be known as Vidhura.
mn50:9.5.comm: At AN 3.20:2.1, vidhura is the cleverness of a shopkeeper in trade, illustrating the “indefatigable” mendicant in striving.

mn50:10.1.pli: Āyasmā pana, pāpima, sañjīvo araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi appakasireneva saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjati.
mn50:10.1.eng: But when Venerable Sañjīva had gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he easily attained the cessation of perception and feeling.

mn50:10.2.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, pāpima, āyasmā sañjīvo aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno nisinno hoti.
mn50:10.2.eng: Once upon a time, Sañjīva was sitting at the root of a certain tree having attained the cessation of perception and feeling.

mn50:10.3.pli: Addasaṃsu kho, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino āyasmantaṃ sañjīvaṃ aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannaṃ nisinnaṃ;
mn50:10.3.eng: Some cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him sitting there

mn50:10.6.eng: This ascetic passed away while seated.

mn50:10.8.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca gomayañca saṅkaḍḍhitvā āyasmato sañjīvassa kāye upacinitvā aggiṃ datvā pakkamiṃsu.
mn50:10.8.eng: They collected grass, wood, and cow-dung, heaped it all on Sañjīva’s body, set it on fire, and left.

mn50:11.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, āyasmā sañjīvo tassā rattiyā accayena tāya samāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā cīvarāni papphoṭetvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn50:11.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, Sañjīva emerged from that attainment, shook out his robes, and, since it was morning, he robed up and entered the village for alms.

mn50:11.2.pli: Addasaṃsu kho te, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino āyasmantaṃ sañjīvaṃ piṇḍāya carantaṃ;
mn50:11.2.eng: Those cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him wandering for alms

mn50:11.5.pli: Ayaṃ samaṇo nisinnakova kālaṅkato, svāyaṃ paṭisañjīvito’ti.
mn50:11.5.eng: This ascetic passed away while seated, and now he has come back to life!’

mn50:11.6.pli: Iminā kho evaṃ, pāpima, pariyāyena āyasmato sañjīvassa sañjīvoteva samaññā udapādi.
mn50:11.6.eng: And that’s how he came to be known as Sañjīva.

mn50:12.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, dūsissa mārassa etadahosi:
mn50:12.1.eng: Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī,

mn50:12.2.pli: ‘imesaṃ kho ahaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ neva jānāmi āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā.
mn50:12.2.eng: ‘I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character.
mn50:12.2.comm: The idiom āgatiṁ vā gatiṁ vā, literally “comings and goings”, refers to the “course of rebirth”.

mn50:12.3.eng: Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say,

mn50:12.4.pli: etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosatha paribhāsatha rosetha vihesetha.
mn50:12.4.eng: “Come, all of you, abuse, attack, harass, and trouble the ethical mendicants of good character.
mn50:12.4.comm: Māra urges and encourages, but does not control their behavior, so they are still responsible for their deeds.

mn50:12.5.pli: Appeva nāma tumhehi akkosiyamānānaṃ paribhāsiyamānānaṃ rosiyamānānaṃ vihesiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.
mn50:12.5.eng: Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’

mn50:12.6.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, dūsī māro brāhmaṇagahapatike anvāvisi:
mn50:12.6.eng: And that’s exactly what he did.

mn50:12.7.pli: ‘etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosatha paribhāsatha rosetha vihesetha.

mn50:12.8.pli: Appeva nāma tumhehi akkosiyamānānaṃ paribhāsiyamānānaṃ rosiyamānānaṃ vihesiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.

mn50:13.1.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, brāhmaṇagahapatikā anvāvisiṭṭhā dūsinā mārena bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosanti paribhāsanti rosenti vihesenti:
mn50:13.1.eng: Then those brahmins and householders abused, attacked, harassed, and troubled the ethical mendicants of good character:

mn50:13.2.pli: ‘ime pana muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.
mn50:13.2.eng: ‘These shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman, say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” Shoulders drooping, downcast, and dopey, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.
mn50:13.2.comm: The phrase “meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate” (jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti) uses a series of verbs from the same root as jhāna with different prefixes to satirical effect. See also AN 6.46:2.2, AN 11.9:2.10, and MN 108:26.4.

mn50:13.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma ulūko rukkhasākhāyaṃ mūsikaṃ maggayamāno jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
mn50:13.3.eng: They’re just like an owl on a branch, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse.

mn50:13.4.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.

mn50:13.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kotthu nadītīre macche maggayamāno jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
mn50:13.5.eng: They’re just like a jackal on a river-bank, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a fish.

mn50:13.6.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.

mn50:13.7.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma biḷāro sandhisamalasaṅkaṭīre mūsikaṃ maggayamāno jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
mn50:13.7.eng: They’re just like a cat by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse.

mn50:13.8.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.

mn50:13.9.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gadrabho vahacchinno sandhisamalasaṅkaṭīre jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
mn50:13.9.eng: They’re just like an unladen donkey by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates.

mn50:13.10.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyantī’ti.
mn50:13.10.eng: In the same way, these shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman, say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” Shoulders drooping, downcast, and dopey, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.’

mn50:13.11.pli: Ye kho pana, pāpima, tena samayena manussā kālaṃ karonti yebhuyyena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
mn50:13.11.eng: Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn50:14.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn50:14.1.eng: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:

mn50:14.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī.

mn50:14.3.pli: etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosatha paribhāsatha rosetha vihesetha, appeva nāma tumhehi akkosiyamānānaṃ paribhāsiyamānānaṃ rosiyamānānaṃ vihesiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.
mn50:14.3.eng: He told them to abuse you in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.

mn50:14.4.pli: Etha, tumhe, bhikkhave, mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatha, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharatha.
mn50:14.4.eng: Come, all of you mendicants, meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn50:14.4.comm: These meditations counteract the tendency to anger.

mn50:14.5.eng: Meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

mn50:14.6.eng: Meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

mn50:14.7.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatha, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharathā’ti.
mn50:14.7.eng: Meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

mn50:15.1.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, bhikkhū kakusandhena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānā araññagatāpi rukkhamūlagatāpi suññāgāragatāpi mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihariṃsu, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā vihariṃsu.
mn50:15.1.eng: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated spreading a heart full of love …

mn50:15.4.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihariṃsu, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā vihariṃsu.

mn50:16.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, dūsissa mārassa etadahosi:
mn50:16.1.eng: Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī,

mn50:16.2.pli: ‘evampi kho ahaṃ karonto imesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ neva jānāmi āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā, yannūnāhaṃ brāhmaṇagahapatike anvāviseyyaṃ:
mn50:16.2.eng: ‘Even when I do this I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character. Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say,

mn50:16.3.pli: “etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkarotha garuṃ karotha mānetha pūjetha,
mn50:16.3.eng: “Come, all of you, honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the ethical mendicants of good character.

mn50:16.4.pli: appeva nāma tumhehi sakkariyamānānaṃ garukariyamānānaṃ māniyamānānaṃ pūjiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran”’ti.
mn50:16.4.eng: Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’
mn50:16.4.comm: Māra did not want to genuinely respect the mendicants, but to corrupt them with adulation.

mn50:17.1.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, dūsī māro brāhmaṇagahapatike anvāvisi:
mn50:17.1.eng: And that’s exactly what he did.

mn50:17.2.pli: ‘etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkarotha garuṃ karotha mānetha pūjetha,

mn50:17.3.pli: appeva nāma tumhehi sakkariyamānānaṃ garukariyamānānaṃ māniyamānānaṃ pūjiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.

mn50:17.4.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, brāhmaṇagahapatikā anvāviṭṭhā dūsinā mārena bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti.
mn50:17.4.eng: Then those brahmins and householders honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated the ethical mendicants of good character.

mn50:17.5.pli: Ye kho pana, pāpima, tena samayena manussā kālaṃ karonti yebhuyyena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
mn50:17.5.eng: Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn50:18.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn50:18.1.eng: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:

mn50:18.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī.

mn50:18.3.pli: “etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkarotha garuṃ karotha mānetha pūjetha,
mn50:18.3.eng: He told them to venerate you

mn50:18.4.pli: appeva nāma tumhehi sakkariyamānānaṃ garukariyamānānaṃ māniyamānānaṃ pūjiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran”ti.
mn50:18.4.eng: in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.

mn50:18.5.pli: Etha, tumhe, bhikkhave, asubhānupassino kāye viharatha, āhāre paṭikūlasaññino, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññino, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassino’ti.
mn50:18.5.eng: Come, all you mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.’

mn50:19.1.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, bhikkhū kakusandhena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānā araññagatāpi rukkhamūlagatāpi suññāgāragatāpi asubhānupassino kāye vihariṃsu, āhāre paṭikūlasaññino, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññino, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassino.
mn50:19.1.eng: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.

mn50:20.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya āyasmatā vidhurena pacchāsamaṇena gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn50:20.1.eng: Then the Buddha Kakusandha robed up in the morning and, taking this bowl and robe, entered the village for alms with Venerable Vidhura as his second monk.

mn50:21.1.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, dūsī māro aññataraṃ kumārakaṃ anvāvisitvā sakkharaṃ gahetvā āyasmato vidhurassa sīse pahāramadāsi; sīsaṃ vobhindi.
mn50:21.1.eng: Then Māra Dūsī took possession of a certain boy, picked up a rock, and hit Vidhura on the head, cracking it open.

mn50:21.2.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, āyasmā vidhuro bhinnena sīsena lohitena gaḷantena kakusandhaṃyeva bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
mn50:21.2.eng: Then Vidhura, with blood pouring from his cracked skull, still followed behind the Buddha Kakusandha.
mn50:21.2.comm: Yeva (“still”) has an adversative sense here (see AN 3.82:1.4).

mn50:21.3.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho nāgāpalokitaṃ apalokesi:
mn50:21.3.eng: Then the Buddha Kakusandha turned to gaze back, the way that elephants do, saying,
mn50:21.3.comm: Nāgāpalokitaṁ, the “elephant look”, was famously employed by the Buddha as he made his final departure from Vesālī (DN 16:4.1.2). There is a similar Sanskrit term siṁhāvalokana, the “lion look”, said to be the slow glance back that a lion makes as he leaves his kill.

mn50:21.5.pli: Sahāpalokanāya ca pana, pāpima, dūsī māro tamhā ca ṭhānā cavi mahānirayañca upapajji.
mn50:21.5.eng: And as he was gazing, Māra Dūsī fell from that place and was reborn in the Great Hell.
mn50:21.5.comm: The Pali sahāpalokanāya makes it clear that Māra fell to hell while the Buddha was looking, not because he looked. | More details on hell are provided in MN 129 and MN 130.

mn50:22.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, pāpima, mahānirayassa tayo nāmadheyyā honti—
mn50:22.1.eng: Now that Great Hell is known by three names:

mn50:22.2.pli: chaphassāyataniko itipi, saṅkusamāhato itipi, paccattavedaniyo itipi.
mn50:22.2.eng: ‘Related to the Six Fields of Contact’ and also ‘The Impaling With Spikes’ and also ‘Uniquely Painful’.
mn50:22.2.comm: The hell “Related to the Six Fields of Contact” and its corresponding heaven are further discussed at SN 35.135. | The sense of paccattavedaniya (“Uniquely Painful”) is clarified in the verses (MN 50:24.6).

mn50:22.3.pli: Atha kho maṃ, pāpima, nirayapālā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
mn50:22.3.eng: Then the wardens of hell came to me and said,

mn50:22.4.pli: ‘yadā kho te, mārisa, saṅkunā saṅku hadaye samāgaccheyya.
mn50:22.4.eng: ‘When spike meets spike in your heart,

mn50:22.6.eng: you’ve been roasting in hell for a thousand years.’

mn50:23.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, pāpima, bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni tasmiṃ mahāniraye apacciṃ.
mn50:23.1.eng: I roasted for many years, many centuries, many millennia in that Great Hell.

mn50:23.2.pli: Dasavassasahassāni tasseva mahānirayassa ussade apacciṃ vuṭṭhānimaṃ nāma vedanaṃ vediyamāno.
mn50:23.2.eng: For ten thousand years I roasted in the annex of that Great Hell, experiencing the pain called ‘this is emergence’.
mn50:23.2.comm: I think vuṭṭhānimaṁ (“this is emergence”) simply means the feeling that is experienced on “emergence” from the Great Hell to the annex. The commentary, however, says it means the “feeling that emerges as a result of kamma”.

mn50:23.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, pāpima, evarūpo kāyo hoti, seyyathāpi manussassa.
mn50:23.3.eng: My body was in human form,

mn50:23.4.eng: but I had the head of a fish.

mn50:28.4.eng: the one who is freed through the ending of craving?’
mn50:28.4.comm: Moggallāna asked Sakka if he remembered the teaching on this topic that he had received from the Buddha (MN 37:8.1). | The compound taṇhākkhayavimuttiyo is translated as a feminine plural by Norman in Elders’ Verses, but MN 37:2.2 refers to “the mendicant who is freed” in singular. Resolve to taṇhākkhayavimutti yo; vimutti agrees with yo as the nominative singular of the masculine agent noun in -in, which occurs in the same phrase at AN 4.38:6.2 and Iti 55:4.2.

mn50:29.2.eng: in the Hall of Clear Right before the assembly:
mn50:29.2.comm: This retells the events of SN 6.5, but there there is no mention of the Hall of Justice.

mn50:29.4.eng: that you had in the past?

mn50:29.13.eng: So how could I say today

mn50:29.14.eng: that I am permanent and eternal?’

mn50:30.1.eng: I’m the one who touched the peak of Mount Meru

mn50:30.2.eng: using the power of meditative liberation.

mn50:30.3.eng: I’ve visited the forests of the people

mn50:30.4.eng: who dwell in the land east of Videha.

mn50:31.8.eng: like a fool touching the flames.

mn50:31.15.eng: Give up on the Buddha, Māra!

mn50:31.16.eng: And hold no hope for the mendicants!”

mn50:31.17.comm: The commentary to Thag 20.1:69.1 says that this verse was added at the Council.

mn50:32.4.pli: Dūsī ca māro dasamo ca vaggo.
